Heil To Quake




In the realm of classic first-person shooters, my enduring passion traces its roots back to 1996 with the iconic game Quake developed by id Software. Over the years, my infatuation with this timeless masterpiece has only deepened, leading me to revisit its virtual landscapes pretty much on a regular basis.

Quake was one of the first fully 3D first-person shooter games. It has its influences from Doom in terms of gameplay, design, and story, and it played truly a pivotal role in modernizing FPS gaming. I personally consider it to be the progenitor of contemporary first-person shooters. Especially noteworthy is the fact that the first Half-Life released in 1998 operated on the Quake Engine.

This detail underscores its profound impact, as its engine served as the technological backbone for one of the most influential and groundbreaking titles of its time.




My unwavering devotion towards Quake is undoubtedly deep. It holds a profound emotional significance for me, and even now, it has the power to resonate with the deepest chords of my heart, evoking a sense of nostalgia and tenderness. It’s astounding how the distinctive style, aesthetic, and gameplay continue to captivate me, despite how old and “outdated” it is.

From the gruesome monsters to the meticulously crafted maps, the immersive Lovecraftian environments, the atmospheric ambiance, the iconic arsenal of weapons and their respective sounds – every element of Quake contributes to its timeless allure.

This piece of software is not just a game for me; it’s a mix of memories and feelings that have stood the test of time, creating a connection that goes beyond pixels and lines of code. It’s not rare for me to contemplate how adeptly this game encapsulates nearly everything I appreciate and hold dear.





Despite being not as popular as his older brother Doom, it brings me joy to witness the ongoing enthusiasm and activity within this game’s community, particularly among mod developers. Their dedication to crafting and delivering extraordinary experiences, exemplified by projects like Quake 1.5/Combat+, Epsilon, and a favorite of mine, Peril, is truly commendable.

In Peril, players step into the shoes of Robyn, the daughter of one of the first rangers sent through the Slip-gates.

I highly suggest you download either Quakespasm Spiked or Iron Wail and you give it a try! The enormous and detailed maps, along with the unique atmospheres, are truly impressive and fun to play.

You can download it on ModDB.







For newcomers looking to experience the title in its original form without substantial modifications or new/altered content, I strongly recommend downloading the Darkplaces engine. Customize it according to your preferences, and dive into the game for an authentic but at the same time enhanced experience!

For those who might not be too tech-savvy, the Quake Remastered version on Steam provides a user-friendly alternative and it offers a polished and updated experience.
